text: Julia compiler is really doing amazing optimizations under the hood, see e.g. <https://github.com/JuliaData/DataFrames.jl/pull/2610#discussion_r567454074> for a recent discussion.

elements.text: Julia compiler is really doing amazing optimizations under the hood, see e.g.

text: Yeah. The coolest thing recently I saw was when I investigated why it was possible that some code I had with long chains of if elseif elseif ... was fast. Turned out that part of the explanation was that the compiler lay out the native code of the branches next to each other in memory, then directly computed the memory location of the correct branch to jump to and jumped to that. I was blown away

elements.text: Yeah. The coolest thing recently I saw was when I investigated why it was possible that some code I had with long chains of if elseif elseif ... was fast. Turned out that part of the explanation was that the compiler lay out the native code of the branches next to each other in memory, then directly computed the memory location of the correct branch to jump to and jumped to that. I was blown away

text: iirc, jump tables are a LLVM feature

elements.text: iirc, jump tables are a LLVM feature

text: that's why dispatch is for choosing a method, not for implementing logic ;)

elements.text: that's why dispatch is for choosing a method, not for implementing logic ;)

text: I like letting Jeff et. al. doing all this heavy lifting, making my nice generic Julia code run super fast :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I like letting Jeff et. al. doing all this heavy lifting, making my nice generic Julia code run super fast

text: (the list of people I wish to thank on a daily basis has grown unwieldly large! :slightly_smiling_face: )
